messages.subject: [Unschooling-dotcom] Re:Fines for Truancy ?
messages.msgSnippet: ... So isn t there a local support group challenging this outrageous situtation? If not, why not start one? This isn t a support group, it s a discussion list.
messages.messageBody:
At 1:55 PM -0400 8/24/02, Luz Shosie and Ned Vare wrote:
>PS Such an outrageous situation as this needs to be challenged. What are
>support groups for, if not this?

So isn't there a local support group challenging this outrageous
situtation? If not, why not start one?

This isn't a support group, it's a discussion list. Pretty big difference.

Helen

messages.subject: Re:Fines for Truancy ?
messages.msgSnippet: on 8/24/02 9:40 AM, Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com at ... So, it s just like the bandit says, Your money or your life !  Only the schools (in PA at
messages.messageBody:
on 8/24/02 9:40 AM, Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com at
Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com wrote:

>> << She has to go enough so that she doesn't start getting truancy
>> fines. Truancy fines can get very, very expensive... >>
>>


So, it's just like the bandit says, "Your money or your life !" Only the
schools (in PA at least) add a twist: "Your money or your kid's body."

In our state, CT, a child can't be considered truant if s/he is not enrolled
in a school. Therefore, homeschoolers are not liable under "truancy."

A child needs to be "absent" in order to be "truant." Homeschoolers are not
"absent."

Ned Vare
PS Such an outrageous situation as this needs to be challenged. What are
support groups for, if not this?
